content: The Vedic period sees the region of Bengal mentioned as Vanga in ancient texts, with early settlements and agricultural practices.
The kingdom of Anga, part of present-day West Bengal, is mentioned in the Mahabharata and flourishes as a trade hub.
The Mauryan Empire under Emperor Ashoka includes Bengal, spreading Buddhism and establishing administrative control.
The Gupta Empire influences Bengal, with advancements in literature, art, and science, and the composition of Sanskrit texts.
The Gauda Kingdom under King Shashanka emerges as a powerful state, promoting Hinduism and early Bengali culture.
The Pala Empire, known for its patronage of Buddhism, art, and education, dominates Bengal and establishes Nalanda and Vikramashila Universities.
The Delhi Sultanate conquers Bengal, leading to the rise of Islamic culture and architecture in the region.
The Bengal Sultanate is established, fostering an independent Islamic kingdom with trade connections across the Indian Ocean.
The Mughal Empire annexes Bengal, making it a prosperous province under rulers like Akbar and Aurangzeb.
Job Charnock, an agent of the British East India Company, establishes a trading post in Kolkata, laying the foundation for the city.
The Battle of Plassey marks the beginning of British rule in India, with Bengal as the first province to come under direct British control.
Raja Ram Mohan Roy founds the Brahmo Samaj in Kolkata, initiating social and religious reform movements in Bengal.
The Bengal Renaissance begins, with cultural icons like Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar, Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay, and Rabindranath Tagore emerging.
The Partition of Bengal by the British sparks widespread protests, uniting people across religious and cultural lines.
India gains independence, and Bengal is divided into West Bengal (India) and East Bengal (Pakistan, later Bangladesh).
West Bengal plays a key role in supporting the Bangladesh Liberation War, hosting millions of refugees and aiding the cause.
Satyajit Ray, a filmmaker from Bengal, wins an Honorary Academy Award, bringing global recognition to Bengali cinema.
The Sundarbans, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, gains prominence for its unique mangrove ecosystem and conservation efforts.
The Trinamool Congress comes to power in West Bengal, marking a major political shift after decades of Left Front rule.
The Durga Puja of West Bengal is recognized as an Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity by UNESCO.
